PHCSE Equity Statement:

Penn Hills Charter School of Entrepreneurship (PHCSE) recognizes that we are part of an academic and cultural community committed to fostering integrity, respect, and justice. Aiming to learn from each other, we reject all forms of prejudice and discrimination. To ensure this, our school will continue to adopt and use inclusive practices and programs that create an opportunity for all. In the classroom, we promote active learning about diversity that allows both students and faculty to effectively acquire cultural competence. Both in and beyond the classroom, we envision an inclusive community.

PHCSE does not discriminate within its educational programs, activities, or against stakeholders. Students are educated in programs that foster knowledge, respect, and appreciation for the historical and contemporary contributions of diverse cultural groups to society which includes those of all sexual orientations, race, color, national origin, gender, gender identity, disability, religion, creed, and socioeconomic status.

Today, Mr. Jones presented Dominic Moore and Courtney Wallace Jr., 7th grade students at The Neighborhood Academy, with a $500 check for coming in first place at the 3rd Annual Soaring Shark Tank Pitch Competition on May 15, 2020. Please join us in congratulating these innovative scholars!

Learning can take many forms.

In Senora Creach's class students made Mexican sugar cookies which are very yummy.

Students had the option to do a "Receta" after completing work this week. Here is what Morgan Parks, a first grader chose "Polvorones"

If you would like to make your own, you can follow the recipe below.

Mexican sugar cookies
2 cups flour
3/4 cup sugar
1/2 tsp cinnamon
1 cup butter or margarine
Preheat oven to 300 F.
In a bowl, stir together flour, sugar and cinnamon.
Cream butter with a beater.
Add flour mixture 1/2 cup at a time to the butter while still beating until it is all incorporated.
Use a teaspoon to spoon out small pieces of dough and shape into a cookie.
Place on ungreased cookie sheets and bake 25 minutes.
Optional: sprinkle warm cookies with sugar and cinnamon
Makes 24 cookies

Faculty / Staff Spotlight!!

Meet Linda Porter, our Administrative Assistant at PHCSE. Ms. Linda has been with us for 6 years.

Third Grade students researched the contributions of author, Carmen Rubin and Dr. Mae Jemison, the first African American Woman in space.
Carmen Rubin who has worked with many notable figures, such as Dwyane Wade, and former First Lady Michelle Obama, has donated signed copies of her book "Honcho Hates Mud" to Ms. Gilmore's class.
Students enjoyed finding Carmen's secret message about "kindness" in her books.
Students in Mrs. Padovano's class, shared their thoughts on how Dr. Mae Jemison has inspired them to reach for the stars.

In celebration of #BlackHistoryMonth, each grade level will focus on African American influencers by examining their history, contributions, and impact they had in efforts to lead and inspire.

Second Grade students focused on two prominent African American artists, Jean Michel Basquiat, and Baron Batch. Basquiat is known for his art to reflect social commentary and is the only African American artist to have his artwork sold at auction for $110.5 million dollars. Mr. Batch, a former Steelers football player, began painting while recovering from an injury. He is known for giving away his paintings that include inspirational messages. Both of these artists inspire our students to be brave and creative.

"The best thing about this school is how the faculty and staff treat each other and the students like family, and that is what brings me joy coming to work."

Whether it's monitoring the hallways or directing traffic for arrivals and dismissals, he is always there to greet you with a smile on his face while keeping our school safe.

Thank you Officer Kenny for everything you do!
